current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

quote.#text: United States and India Partnership Day

cosponsor.#tail: ) submitted the following resolution; which was considered and agreed to

quote.#tail:
, recognizing the contributions of the United States and India to one another and their
			 relationship that will continue to help define the 21st century; and
quote.#text: United States and India Partnership Day

text.#text:
recognizes that the relationship between the United States and India is a special and permanent
			 bond.

Whereas the United States, the oldest democracy in the world,  will welcome the 
			 Prime
			 Minister of India, the leader of the largest democracy in the world, to
			 the
			 Nation's capital, on
			 September 30, 2014;

Whereas the United States–India relationship is built on mutual respect for common
			 values, including democracy, the rule of law, a market economy, and ethnic
			 and religious diversity, and is bolstered by strong people-to-people
			 connections, including a 3,000,000 strong Indian American diaspora;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
places tremendous value on the relationship between the United States and India,
			 and the bipartisan Senate India Caucus comprises 42 Senators
			 and is the largest country-specific caucus in the

congratulated the Prime Minister of India after his
			 party's election
			 victory and
			 emphasized the

quote.#tail: in India and the United States;
quote.#text: deep bond and commitment to promoting economic opportunity, freedom, and security

text.#text:
Whereas the 2 largest democracies in the world, the United States and India, have further developed
			 their governments, businesses, nonprofit organizations, nongovernmental
			 organizations, artists, entertainers,
			 athletes, scientists, engineers, doctors, nurses, universities,
			 schools, and faiths and the dignity of their citizens by demonstrating the
			 value
			 of an enlightened democratic rule of law, a peaceful government, and
			 freedom from terror, tyranny, and oppression;

Whereas the relationship between the United States and India is vital to promoting stability,
			 democracy, and economic prosperity in the 21st century;

Whereas bilateral trade between the United States and India increased from $19,000,000,000 in 2000
			 to $95,000,000,000 in 2013;

Whereas in 2013, the United
			 States exported goods to India totaling $35,000,000,000 and generating
			 168,000 jobs in the United States; and

Whereas in 2013, the United States invested  more than $28,000,000,000 in India, generating more
			 than 500,000 jobs
			 in India: Now, therefore, be it

{http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/}title.#text: 113 SRES 571 ATS: Designating September 30, 2014, as “United States and India Partnership Day”.
